Topic.Title: Major banks set to finalize the last penalty payment for improper foreclosures......

Message.Msg: Your answer makes no sense. I can see it costs the banks less money but only so in the actual processing of the foreclosures. How much will the homeowners really get from this deal? Also have you checked the amount of NODs that have been filed in November and December? In one word....LOTS of them. In San Diego for example, there were over 130 NODs in December alone! Also, that is only San Diego proper, I did not check the entire county. With the recent surge in housing prices, I believe the banks want to start to unwind their inventories of distressed properties. The big question in my mind is will the public and investors consume most of these properties to the point that it will eliminate most of the inventory by end of summer of 2014? Also, how will the recent NODs effect the housing market. We are clearly not out of the woods.

Message.Title: BAC will be #1 stock in Dow 2013
Message.Msg: All stocks are rising this morning as fast as BAC. The difference is, BAC has a huge burden still as a result of the past housing crisis (many underwater loans on their books). However, as the stock market rises and puts more money in people's pockets, and the economy picks up (even slightly helps) then those underwater mortgages become ABOVE water mortgages and go from bad loans to good loans. Therefore, BAC gets a double kick once we start to report earnings as housing is turning around faster than most think. BAC should be $15 by end of march and $18 by Dec/2013, year end.

Message.Msg: y Alexandra Scaggs After a year when Bank of America BAC +3.88% stock more than doubled, Evercore Partners emphasized its bullish view on the stock for the New Year. Associated Press The investment bank says the nation’s second-biggest bank by assets is its top pick for a large-cap bank in 2013, adding it to its conviction list. Analyst Andrew Marquardt thinks the capital concerns are “behind” BofA, so investors will start to focus on its earnings power, which the analyst has high hopes for. He sees 2013 EPS at $1.69 a share, 76% above consensus estimates, as measured by Thomson Reuters. BofA replaces Wells Fargo as WFC +2.33% the analyst’s top pick, one of the several banks he cut based on lower earnings expectations since banks will struggle to improve margins because of low interest rates. Bank of America, however, has more control over its earnings power, Marquardt said, thanks to expense cuts and the ability to reprice its debt. In upgrading the best performing Dow Jones stock of 2012, Marquardt follows in the footsteps of Meredith Whitney, who upgraded shares last month. BofA shares so far on track to continue amid a broad financial rally thanks to the fiscal-cliff aversion. The shares are jumping 4.5% to $12.13, the stock’s for the first time above $12 since May 2011.

Message.Title: Obama’s leadership failure
Message.Msg: Obama’s leadership failure...The Washington Post Published: December 31 The “fiscal cliff” is a massive failure of presidential leadership. The tedious and technical negotiations are but a subplot in a larger drama. Government can no longer fulfill all the promises it has made to various constituencies. Some promises will be reduced or disavowed. Which ones? Why? Only the president can pose these questions in a way that starts a national conversation over the choices to be made, but doing so requires the president to tell people things they don’t want to hear. That’s his job: to help Americans face unavoidable, if unpleasant, realities. Barack Obama has refused to play this role.

Message.Msg: Interesting.... Financial stocks surged on the first day of trading in 2013 after Congress reached an agreement that averted the fiscal cliff and analysts and investors expressed renewed optimism, even after the sector posted market-leading gains last year. The PHLX KBW Bank Index was up 2.4% in recent Wednesday trading, exceeding the 1.7% gain in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. It was led by a 3.7% advance in shares of Citigroup Inc. (C), a 2.4% gain for shares of Morgan Stanley (MS) and a 3.3% gain for Bank of America Corp. (BAC). While many regional bank stocks trade above their book value, shares of most banks with sizeable capital-markets operations haven't traded above tangible book value since at least mid-2011. J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. (JPM) is the one exception. Tangible book value is the liquidation value of a company not counting intangible assets such as goodwill. Investors have discounted the value of the big capital markets banks in recent years, but the tide may be turning. Shares of Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS) were trading recently at 98% of tangible book value, helped by a jump of 2.2% Wednesday, according to data by FactSet. The shares have traded below book value since August 2011. Morgan Stanley shares were trading at 77% of book value and have traded below the measure since March 2011. Bank of America were trading at 94% of book value and have been below it since March 2011. Shares of Citi were trading at 80% and have been below book value since January 2011. Monday, analysts at Evercore Partners added Bank of America to their "conviction buy" list, saying the bank has the best valuation among large-capitalization banks and the most flexibility to improve performance. Evercore reiterated its buy rating on the shares even though Bank of America's stock price doubled in 2012. Evercore's $13 price target would value Bank of America above its $12.77 tangible book value as of its most recent quarterly financial statement. Bank of America shares were trading at $11.92 a share Wednesday afternoon. Meanwhile, analysts at Credit Suisse raised their estimates for Goldman's fourth-quarter earnings per share to $4.60 from $2.50, citing a strong finish for the firm's equities and investment-banking divisions and a tough line on expenses. Analysts said Wednesday's gains for financial stocks reflected investor sentiment the worst may be over, at least temporarily. "It's OK to take on risk," said Brad Hintz, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein. Financial stocks posted the biggest gains on a percentage basis in the Standard & Poor's 500 index in 2012, up 29% in the last 12 months versus a 15% gain in the index. Many investors are playing catch up. "There is a big beta chase in financials," said Jones Trading market strategist Yousef Abbasi. "Guys are still underweight and have missed a big move and feel the need to get involved."

Message.Msg: WASHINGTON — Income inequality has soared to the highest levels since the Great Depression, and the recession has done little to reverse the trend, with the top 1 percent of earners taking 93 percent of the income gains in the first full year of the recovery. “Growth becomes more fragile” in countries with high levels of inequality like the United States, said Jonathan D. Ostry of the International Monetary Fund, whose research suggests that the widening disparity since the 1980s might shorten the nation’s economic expansions by as much as a third. Reducing inequality and bolstering growth, in the long run, might be “two sides of the same coin,” research published last year by the I.M.F. concluded. Since the 1980s, rich households in the United States have earned a larger and larger share of overall income. The 1 percent earns about one-sixth of all income and the top 10 percent about half, according to statistics compiled by the respected economists Emmanuel Saez of the University of California, Berkeley and Thomas Piketty of the Paris School of Economics. For years, economists have thought of such inequality in part as a side effect of policies that fostered the country’s economic dynamism — its tax preferences for investment income, for instance. And organizations like the World Bank and the I.M.F., which is based in Washington, have generally not tackled inequality in the world head on. But economists’ thinking has changed sharply in recent years. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development this year warned about the “negative consequences” of the country’s high levels of pay inequality, and suggested an aggressive series of changes to tax and spending programs to tackle it. The I.M.F. has cautioned the United States, too. “Some dismiss inequality and focus instead on overall growth — arguing, in effect, that a rising tide lifts all boats,” a commentary by fund economists said. “When a handful of yachts become ocean liners while the rest remain lowly canoes, something is seriously amiss.” The concentration of income in the hands of the rich might not just mean a more unequal society, economists believe. It might mean less stable economic expansions and sluggish growth. That is the conclusion drawn by two economists at the fund, Mr. Ostry and Andrew G. Berg. They found that in rich countries and poor, inequality strongly correlated with shorter spells of economic expansion and thus less growth over time.

Topic.Title: 2013 BAC Prediction

Message.Msg: Gamblin, I'm glad to see your a BAC bull as well. However on the slide down from $55 to $3 a share during the crisis, BAC issued someone between 3-6 billion new shares. This was major, major dilution my friend. If you recall before the mess, BAC was valued at nearly $450 billion market cap, versus today's minimal $130 billion or so. Clearly to return to $450 (which prob will not occur for a decade), BAC will need to dry-up all the volume, borrowed shares, etc. The only way to achieve this is to spend about $12-$24 billion (assuming the price stays @ $12) and remove 1-2 billion shares off the public market. In essence, BAC needs to remove about 25-40% of shares off the market. This however will cost anywhere from $30 billion to $50 billion. Clearly this will take around 5-7 years to achieve with their current net income. Once the dust settles and lawsuits are behind us, I personally believe BAC could generate about $10-$15 billion in annual net income. Assuming 1/3 is return to shareholders, 1/3 is used for buybacks and 1/3 kept in-house for acquisitions, expansion, future branches, etc. No chance the divided goes about .16 or .20 cents a year. Still a 300-400% increase nonetheless. I surely will not complain if they increase the divy by 300-400% and launch for beginning share buyback program. This would be two positives and technically three since management believes in the future direction of the company. BAC will be $25 by 2014.

Topic.Title: 2013 BAC Prediction

Message.Msg: As logical as that seems history says stock buy backs do not add as they should to share value and Warren Buffet speaks out against them, though he just approved addition funds for BRK shares. With 10.78 outstanding shares buy backs in this case are a must and they will. In this thread it is agreed that the dividend will at least reach .16 to .20. I believe Moynahan wants to reward share holders for the past couple of really bad years and solidify a share price above what it was when he took over. My own biggest argument against my own statements is that if the dividend did go that high then the share buy backs would cost them a lot more and take a lot longer to reduce. I knew I was being bold and probably wrong but an additional 2.3 billion to share holders above your own expectations is not THAT far fetched. Again, I was really just trying to stimulate a little BAC conversation on this board.
